title: Mynydd Troed Walk Route

images.title: Philip Halling / Mynydd Troed in snow
images.caption: Mynydd Troed in snow. Its name literally translates to "Foot Mountain," based how it appears when viewed from the Allt Mawr ridge.

images.title: Alan Bowring / North ridge of Mynydd Troed
images.caption: North ridge of Mynydd Troed. The steep ascent up the north ridge from the Talgarth direction. Sandstone outcrops guard the summit plateau.

images.title: View north off Mynydd Troed by Jeremy Bolwell, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: View north off Mynydd Troed

images.title: Alan Bowring / Summit trig point on Mynydd Troed
images.caption: Summit trig point on Mynydd Troed The whitewashed pillar sits at 609m - just shy of 2000ft at the northern end of the main ridge.

images.title: Path on Mynydd Troed with view to Llangorse Lake by Jeremy Bolwell, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Path on Mynydd Troed with view to Llangorse Lake

images.title: View To Cockit Hill And Beyond by Rude Health, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: View To Cockit Hill And Beyond

images.title: Rhiangoll at Pont Waun Fach by Keith Salvesen, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Rhiangoll at Pont Waun Fach

description: This circular walk climbs to Mynydd Troed and Cockit Hill in the Black Mountains section of the Brecon Beacons National Park. You'll also pass through the attractive valley of the River Rhiangoll on the return leg. The walk starts at Pengenffordd which lies less than a mile to the north east of the mountain. From here you can pick up trails heading west and then south west to the 609 m (1,998 ft) summit. You continue south to Cockit Hill, Mynydd Llangorse and Pentre where you cross a bridge over the river Rhiangoll. The route then follows a bridle track north along the river to return to Pengenffordd. The walk can be extended by heading west to visit the lovely waterside paths at Llangorse Lake .
